repository.corpname: Digital Collections and Archives, Tufts University

physdesc.extent: 6 oversize boxes, 1 record carton, 1 letter box, 3 volumes, 5 reel containers

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into two series: Artifacts; and Visual Materials and Ephemera.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Dr. Samuel Harry Berger (1948-2009), M'73, known warmly as Sam or Sammy to most people, grew up in Queens, New York, where his interest in medicine began at Queens College. He completed the pre-med curriculum with honors and actively participated in Alpha Epsilon Pi fraternity. He and his wife, Marlene, traveled to Boston, MA, where Sam graduated from Tufts University School of Medicine. Sam completed medical training in Pediatrics at Albert Einstein College Of Medicine of Yeshiva University in Bronx, NY. His family settled in Rockland County, New York where he worked as a pediatrician for 30 years. Sam's professional affiliations extended to Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center, where he was assistant clinical professor (1997 - 2001). He joined and then headed a pediatric practice in Bardonia, NY and treated children at Nyack Hospital in Nyack, NY as a staff physician in pediatrics. In November 2006, the Pediatric Society of Rockland County recognized Sam for 30 years of distinguished, dedicated, and excellent service. Sam was an avid memorabilia collector with his primary collection consisting of significant pieces related to Willie Mays' Hall-of-Fame baseball career. Because of the strong connection he developed with Tufts during his years in medical school, he began collecting Tufts memorabilia related to all of Tufts' schools and colleges and became well versed in the history of the university. Dr. Berger passed away on January 19, 2009, and is survived by his wife, Marlene Berger, and his two daughters, Emily Berger (Tufts J'03, M'08) and Mara Erickson. Marlene Berger generously donated her husband's collection of Tufts memorabilia to Tufts Digital Collections and Archives in 2013.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: This collection is comprised of an aggregation of Tufts memorabilia and Tufts- related items largely purchased by Samuel Berger. The collection was donated in two accessions by Samuel Berger and family.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed in August 2013 by Leah Edelman and supervised by Veronica Martzhal, Archivist for University Records and Anne Sauer, Director of Digital Collections and Archives. We weeded duplicate material already in DCA's holdings. Delicate physical objects were wrapped in tissue paper and rehoused in archival boxes, small objects such as ribbons and tickets were stored in mylar sleeves and foldered, and photographs were also stored in mylar sleeves and foldered. Publications that the DCA did not previously hold were moved to their appropriate collection, and noted as Samuel Berger's gift.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection comprises Tufts and Tufts-related memorabilia collected by alumnus Samuel Berger. Materials include sports tickets and programs, publications, photographs, and postcards. Most items date from the early and mid-twentieth century. Many items include representations of Tufts buildings, the Tufts seal, and/or Jumbo, or are items commemorating class years, teams, or clubs at Tufts.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. Any intellectual property rights that the donor possesses have been transferred to Tufts University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Tufts memorabilia including paperweights, pins and charms, dinnerware, ashtrays, pennants, a canvas bag, and a football jersey. Most items date from the early and mid-twentieth century, and feature images of Tufts buildings (primarily Ballou Hall, Goddard Chapel, and Eaton Memorial Library), the Tufts seal, and/or representations of Jumbo. Some of the material, including the canvas bag and pins, are items commemorating class years at Tufts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged loosely chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Inscribed "In grateful acknowledgment Leadership and Service"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains sports tickets and programs, early athletics letter patches, photographs, postcards, Tufts and Tufts-related publications, and small Tufts memorabilia such as ribbons, stickers, and matchbook covers. Most items date from the early and mid-twentieth century. Sports tickets and programs are primarily for football events (with one program for baseball and one for track and field), and early athletics latter patches include baseball, swimming, track, tennis, football, basketball, fencing, rowing, and hockey. Photographs largely document athletic teams, clubs, and organizations (including the Louis Pasteur club and the Officers of Student Army Training Corps), and Tufts buildings. Some postcards have been written on and sent while others are blank; the bulk of postcards contain representations of Tufts buildings. Tufts-related publications include newspapers and books that make mention or contain images of Tufts or Tufts students and faculty,and Tufts publications include newspapers, viewbooks, programs, and calendars. Patches, ribbons, stickers, and matchbook covers include representations of the Tufts seal, the Tufts flag, Jumbo, and the flags of other institutions such as Colgate, Yale, Case Western, CCNY, etc.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged loosely chronologically.

scopecontent.p: Copy number 170 in blue slipcase; Donated by Dr. Samuel Berger; Accession 2010.010; A book of photographs of Tufts University. Prospect, Kentucky: Harmony House, 1988.
